text: The Picture of Dorian Gray
speaker: All

text: Prologue
speaker: All

text: The artist is the creator of beautiful things.
speaker: C1

text:
To reveal art 
and conceal the artist is art's aim.
speaker: C4

text: The moral life of man forms part of the subject-matter of the artist…
speaker: C3

text: but the morality of art consists in the perfect use of an imperfect medium.
speaker: C5

text: No artist desires to prove anything.
speaker: C2

text: No artist has ethical sympathies.
speaker: C6

text: An ethical sympathy in an artist is an unpardonable mannerism of style.
speaker: C5

text: No artist is ever morbid.
speaker: C2

text: The artist can express everything.
speaker: C1

text: Thought and language are to the artist instruments of an art.
speaker: C4

text: Vice and virtue are to the artist materials for an art.
speaker: C5

text: All art is at once surface and symbol.
speaker: C6

text: Those who go beneath the surface do so at their peril.
speaker: C4/3

text: Those who read the symbol do so at their peril.
speaker: C6/1

text: It is the spectator, and not life, that art really mirrors.
speaker: C2

text: Diversity of opinion about a work of art shows that the work is
speaker: C3/1

text: new,
speaker: C4

text: complex,
speaker: C5

text: and vital.
speaker: C5/4

text: (hold brush towards audience) All art is quite useless.(place brushes in jar)
speaker: All

text: C2 holds up a picture frame with ‘Scene 1’ on the back
speaker: C2

text: Scene 1
speaker: C2

text: C2 turns the frame round to reveal a picture of Basil’s Studio and hangs on the wall
speaker: C2

text: Basil Hallward’s Studio.
speaker: C1/3

text: Lord Henry Wotton sat on the corner of the Divan (dress and bring Henry forward).
speaker: C1

text: In the centre of the room, clamped to an upright easel, stood the full-length portrait of a young man of extraordinary personal beauty (Dorian is dressed and brought to stand behind frame).
speaker: C2

text: and in front of it, some little distance away, was sitting the artist himself, Basil Hallward (Basil is dressed and brought forward and sat in front of picture).
speaker: C3

text: (gets up and stands looking at picture) It is your best work, Basil, the best thing you have ever done. You must certainly exhibit it at the Grosvenor.
speaker: Lord Henry

text: I don't think I shall send it anywhere.
speaker: Basil

text: (stretches out again) My dear fellow, why? What odd chaps you painters are! You do anything in the world to gain a reputation. As soon as you have one, you seem to want to throw it away.
speaker: Lord H

text: I know you will laugh at me but I really can't exhibit it. I have put too much of myself into it. (Lord H laughs)
speaker: Basil

text: Who is the young Adonis?
speaker: Lord H

text: Dorian Gray.
speaker: Basil

text: So explain to me why you won’t exhibit his picture.
speaker: Lord H

text: Harry, every portrait that is painted with feeling is a portrait of the artist. It is not the sitter who is revealed by the painter; it is rather the painter who reveals himself. I am afraid that I have shown in this picture the secret of my own soul. (covers it)
speaker: Basil

text: And what is that?
speaker: Lord H

text: Two months ago I went to a crush at Lady Brandon's.
speaker: Basil

text: C1, C2, C3 become guests. Dorian goes one side of them, Basil the other.
speaker: Stage

text: I suddenly became conscious that someone was looking at me. I turned and saw Dorian Gray for the first time. When our eyes met a curious sensation of terror came over me. I knew I’d come face to face with someone would absorb my whole nature, my whole soul, my very art itself. I was afraid and turned to quit the room. I stumbled against Lady Brandon.
speaker: Basil

text: You are not going to run away so soon, Mr. Hallward?
speaker: Lady B (C3)

text: I could not get rid of her.
speaker: Basil

text: Basil, Lady B, C1 & C2 & Dorian enact the following:
speaker: Stage

text: She brought him up to royalties,
speaker: C1

text: and people with stars and garters,
speaker: C2

text: and elderly ladies with gigantic tiaras and parrot noses.
speaker: C1

text: She spoke of me as her dearest friend.
speaker: Basil

text: My dear friend Basil
speaker: Lady B

text: Although I had only met her once before. Suddenly I found myself face to face with the young man. Our eyes met again. It was reckless of me, but I asked Lady Brandon to introduce me to him.
speaker: Basil

text: Charming boy. Poor dear mother and I absolutely inseparable. Quite forget what he does. Afraid he doesn't do anything - oh, yes, plays the piano - or is it the violin, dear Mr.Gray?
speaker: Lady B

text: Neither of us could help laughing, and we became friends at once.
speaker: Basil

text: (chorus to back)
speaker: Stage

text: Laughter is not at all a bad beginning for a friendship, and it is far the best ending for one.
speaker: Lord H

text: I couldn't be happy if I didn't see him every day. He is absolutely necessary to me.
speaker: Basil

text: I thought you would never care for anything but your art, so tell me dear Basil why won’t you exhibit his portrait?
speaker: Lord H

text: There is too much of myself in the thing, Harry - too much of myself! He shall never know anything about it. But the world might guess it, and I will not bare my soul to their shallow prying eyes.
speaker: Basil

text: Tell me, is Dorian Gray very fond of you?
speaker: Lord H

text: Mostly, he is charming to me, but sometimes he seems to delight in giving me pain. Then I feel that I have given away my whole soul.
speaker: Basil

text: Days in summer, Basil, are apt to linger, perhaps you will tire sooner than he will.
speaker: Lord H

text: Harry, don't talk like that. As long as I live, the personality of Dorian Gray will dominate me.
speaker: Basil

text: Those who are faithful know only the trivial side of love: it is the faithless who know love's tragedies. Now I have stayed long enough to miss a dreadful luncheon with my Aunt where the conversation would have been about feeding the poor (he snaps his fingers) My dear fellow, I have just remembered where I heard the name of Dorian Gray.
speaker: Lord H

text: Where? Where was it?
speaker: Basil

text: It was at my aunt, Lady Agatha's.
speaker: Lord H

text: I have discovered a wonderful young man. He is going to help me in the East End. His name is Dorian Gray. He has a very earnest and beautiful nature. (during this gets ready to be greasy young man)
speaker: C2 as Lady A

text: I at once pictured to myself a creature with spectacles and lank hair, horribly freckled, and tramping about on huge feet. I wish I had known it was your friend.
speaker: Lord H

text: I am very glad you didn't, Harry.
speaker: Basil

text: Why?
speaker: Lord H

text: I don't want you to meet him.
speaker: Basil

text: Mr. Dorian Gray sir.
speaker: Butler (C3)

text: Well Basil you’ll have to introduce me now.
speaker: Lord H

text: Show Mr. Gray in, Parker.
speaker: Basil

text: Yes sir.
speaker: Butler

text: Butler prepares Dorian – gives him the piano music.
speaker: Stage

text: C3 holds up a picture frame with ‘Scene 2’ on the back
speaker: Stage

text: Scene 2
speaker: C3

text: C3 turns the frame round to reveal a picture of Lord Fermor’s Chambers
speaker: Stage

text: Lord Henry visits Lord Fermor.
speaker: C1/3

text: At half-past twelve next day Lord Henry Wotton strolled from Curzon Street over to the Albany to call on his uncle, Lord Fermor,
speaker: Lord H

text: (putting on costume for Lord F) a genial if somewhat rough-mannered old bachelor,
speaker: C2

text: He had two large town houses, but preferred to live in chambers (set up Chambers) as it was less trouble, and took most of his meals at his club.
speaker: C3

text: Only England could have produced him, and he always said that the country was going to the dogs.
speaker: C1

text: (ready as Lord F) His principles were out of date, but there was a good deal to be said for his prejudices.
speaker: C2

text: When Lord Henry entered the room,
speaker: Lord H

text: He found his uncle sitting in a rough shooting-coat, smoking a cheroot and grumbling over The Times (C1 hands Lord F a cigar and The Times)
speaker: Lord F

text: Well, Harry, what brings you out so early?  I thought you dandies never got up till two, and were not visible till five.
speaker: Lord F

text: Pure family affection, I assure you, Uncle George.  I want to get something out of you.
speaker: Lord H

text: Money, I suppose.
speaker: Lord F

text: What I want is information: not useful information, of course; useless information.
speaker: Lord H

text: Well, I can tell you anything that is in an English Blue Book, Harry,
speaker: Lord F

text: Mr. Dorian Gray does not belong to Blue Books, Uncle George.
speaker: Lord H

text: Mr. Dorian Gray?  Who is he?
speaker: Lord F

text: He is the late Lord Kelso's grandson.  His mother was a Devereux, Lady Margaret Devereux.  I want you to tell me about his mother.  What was she like?  Whom did she marry?
speaker: Lord H

text: Ah the beautiful Margaret Devereux. Ranaway with a penniless young fellow - a mere nobody, sir, a subaltern in a foot regiment. Poor chap was killed in a duel a few months after the marriage.  They said Kelso got some rascally adventurer, to insult his son-in-law in public.  He brought his daughter back with him, I was told, and she never spoke to him again.  She died within a year.  So she left a son, did she?  What sort of boy is he?  If he is like his mother, he must be good-looking
speaker: Lord F

text: He is very good-looking.
speaker: Lord H

text: I hope he will fall into proper hands. He should have a pot of money waiting for him if Kelso did the right thing by him.
speaker: Lord F

text: Thank you Uncle George.  I always like to know everything about my new friends, and nothing about my old ones.  Now I must say good-bye or I shall be late for lunch.
speaker: Lord H

text: Where are you lunching, Harry?
speaker: Lord F

text: At Aunt Agatha's. I have asked myself and Mr.Gray.  He is her latest protege.
speaker: Lord H

text: Humph! tell your Aunt Agatha, Harry, not to bother me any more with her charity appeals.  I am sick of them.  Why, the good woman thinks that I have nothing to do but to write cheques for her silly fads.
speaker: Lord F

text: All right, Uncle George, I'll tell her, but it won't have any effect. Philanthropic people lose all sense of humanity.  It is their distinguishing characteristic.
speaker: Lord H
